1980.headline: The world confronts polio as a global threat
1980.subtext: Over 350,000 children were paralyzed every year across 125+ countries — nearly 1,000 a day.

1981.headline: Brazil shows polio can be stopped
1981.subtext: A nationwide campaign slashed cases to just 122 in one year.

1982.headline: Brazil drives cases near zero
1982.subtext: Repeated campaigns pushed infections down to around 70.

1983.headline: Dominican Republic eliminates polio
1983.subtext: National Immunization Days ended transmission entirely.

1984.headline: Finland halts a rare outbreak
1984.subtext: Tens of thousands were vaccinated within weeks to stop the spread.

1985.headline: A global citizens’ movement begins
1985.subtext: Rotary launches PolioPlus as the Americas commit to eradication by 1990.

1986.headline: 150 million children vaccinated in one year
1986.subtext: Mass campaigns showed the world what scale was possible.

1987.headline: Investment and vigilance cut cases sharply
1987.subtext: The Americas saw a two-thirds drop thanks to stronger surveillance and funding.

1988.headline: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative launches
1988.subtext: A united plan promised that no child should ever suffer polio again.

1989.headline: Oman outbreak exposes hidden risks
1989.subtext: Despite high routine coverage, polio struck — proving campaigns must go further.

1990.headline: Global lab network takes shape
1990.subtext: More than 140 labs worldwide began tracing the virus sample by sample.

1991.headline: Last indigenous case in the Americas
1991.subtext: Peru recorded the region’s final case, proving continental elimination was possible.

1992.headline: Outbreak strikes unvaccinated groups in Europe
1992.subtext: Dozens were paralyzed in vaccine-refusing communities in the Netherlands.

1993.headline: United States confirms no wild polio circulation
1993.subtext: Surveillance showed the virus was gone after decades of fear.

1994.headline: The Americas certified polio-free
1994.subtext: From Canada to Chile, families celebrated a polio-free future.

1995.headline: India launches Pulse Polio Days
1995.subtext: Nearly 90 million children were vaccinated in a single day — twice.

1996.headline: Mandela calls to 'Kick Polio Out of Africa'
1996.subtext: A movement across 50+ countries galvanized leaders and communities.

1997.headline: Last wild case in Western Pacific
1997.subtext: Cambodia reported the region’s final infection.

1998.headline: Europe records its last indigenous case
1998.subtext: Turkey reported the region’s final wild case of polio.

1999.headline: Last case of polio type 2 recorded
1999.subtext: A child in India was the final case of a strain later declared eradicated.

2000.headline: Western Pacific certified polio-free
2000.subtext: 550 million children had been immunized across the region.

2001.headline: Fewer endemic countries, new risks
2001.subtext: Wild polio dropped below 1,000 cases, but dangerous flare-ups emerged.

2002.headline: Europe certified polio-free
2002.subtext: Nearly 870 million people now lived in certified regions.

2003.headline: Vaccine suspensions trigger global spread
2003.subtext: A pause in northern Nigeria re-seeded outbreaks in 20+ countries.

2004.headline: Africa unites in synchronized campaigns
2004.subtext: 20 countries coordinated to vaccinate 80 million children in days.

2005.headline: Sharper tools target stubborn outbreaks
2005.subtext: New monovalent vaccines gave health workers faster control.

2006.headline: Only four endemic countries remain
2006.subtext: Afghanistan, India, Nigeria, and Pakistan were the final frontlines.

2007.headline: 400 million children vaccinated in a year
2007.subtext: Health workers crossed mountains and rivers to reach every last child.

2008.headline: Outbreaks sweep across West Africa
2008.subtext: Importations sparked new cases in more than 20 countries.

2009.headline: Central Africa outbreaks contained
2009.subtext: Rapid campaigns stopped the virus before it could spread further.

2010.headline: Explosive outbreaks in Tajikistan and Congo stopped
2010.subtext: Nearly 900 cases were contained within months by rapid response.

2011.headline: India records its last polio case
2011.subtext: In a nation of 1.2 billion, polio went from 741 cases to zero in two years.

2012.headline: Last case of polio type 3 recorded
2012.subtext: Nigeria reported the final infection of a strain later declared eradicated.

2013.headline: Vaccination continues despite war
2013.subtext: 22 million children were immunized in Syria and Iraq amid conflict.

2014.headline: South-East Asia certified; WHO declares global emergency
2014.subtext: 1.8 billion people gained polio-free status even as spread was declared an emergency.

2015.headline: Polio type 2 eradicated worldwide
2015.subtext: Certification confirmed one of three wild strains was gone forever.

2016.headline: The largest vaccine switch in history
2016.subtext: 150 countries changed formulations within weeks to stay ahead of the virus.

2017.headline: Vaccine-derived outbreaks outnumber wild cases
2017.subtext: Wild polio hit a record low of 22 cases as new flare-ups grew.

2018.headline: Technology sharpens the hunt
2018.subtext: Digital surveillance tools helped find the virus faster than ever.

2019.headline: Type 3 polio declared eradicated
2019.subtext: Two of three wild forms were officially gone.

2020.headline: Africa certified free of wild polio
2020.subtext: Despite COVID-19, 1.8 billion people across 47 countries reached this milestone.

2021.headline: New vaccine and new access
2021.subtext: A next-generation vaccine rolled out as Afghanistan resumed nationwide campaigns.

2022.headline: Polio resurfaces in wealthy countries
2022.subtext: A paralysis case in New York and virus in London sewage showed no country is safe.

2023.headline: Mixed progress with new tools
2023.subtext: Wild cases shrank to 12, but outbreaks spread to 8 more countries.

2024.headline: Dozens of outbreaks tracked and tackled
2024.subtext: WHO mapped 74 flare-ups in 39 countries, triggering rapid drives.

2025.headline: The finish line is in sight
2025.subtext: Polio is reduced by 99%, but the last 1% is the hardest and riskiest to ignore.
